Hi Marvin,

Interesting points, thanks.

It's good to get the input from so=
meone who's deep in the trenches and who
doesn't have the flexibility that =
a lot of us take for granted (such as
installing anything we want or even s=
uggesting upgrades for no other reasons
than technical ones).

I'll address=
 your last question:

On 9/15/06, Marvin Toll <MarvinToll@...> wro=
te:
>
> So - what I'm having trouble cost justifying is introducing a
> run=
time influencing technology that simply is a stylistic
> programming change=
 - from "test" to "@Test".  There is no value-add
> here.  Right?  No addit=
ional value to customers and no additional
> value to developers.  It is si=
mply style.
>
> Or, am I fundamentally missing something.


Here is how I p=
itch annotations for testing.

First of all, putting "test" in front of a t=
est method is really "adding
metadata to that method".  You want to keep th=
e method, but you are also
adding information for a specific, and telling t=
his tool that this method
has a specific status.  Now imagine that you want=
 to do the same thing for,
say, a tool that will automatically generate RMI=
 stubs, and suddenly your
methods need to be called "testRemoteFoo()".  You=
 can see where this leads.

The obvious place for this kind of information =
is in annotations.

This "older" way is also very intrusive:  it forces you=
 to certain namings
(methods start with "test"), certain structural constra=
ints ("have to extend
a given base class", which is a big deal in Java sinc=
e we only have one shot
at that) and also imposes you to a certain package =
hierarchy to keep track
of what tests are and where (package test.db, test.=
gui, etc...).

Once you embrace annotations and, in the case of TestNG, tes=
t groups, you
regain complete freedom to write your Java code the way you w=
ant.  In
effect, your test classes look a lot more like simple Java code (i=
f you
remove the annotations).

Additionally, test groups (@Test(groups =3D=
 {"db", "fast"}) cleanly separate
your test structure from your Java struct=
ure.  You are free to put your
classes in whatever package you like, and yo=
u will specify their test
category in these groups (additionally, test meth=
ods can belong to more than
one group, something you can't do if you're usi=
ng package to organize your
tests).
